page.title: 19A rural studies museum
page.content: Just outside Launceston at a hamlet called Tremeale is a rural studies museum. Last year roughly 2,000 adults and children came to the museum which was started by Mr Howe out of personal interest. The museum houses machinery from the farms nearby and transport from the past.The oldest piece of machinery is a cider mill which is 240 years old and an apple crusher whch is over 200 years old. The buildings in which the machinery is kept are over 295 years old and on the land around are shire horses,jersey cows and a few hens as well as domestic pets. The museum proves that life on the farm today is much safer than 100 years ago. The admission charge is 60p for adults and 30p for children. The museum is well worth a visit .
